editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: Lay her aloof, the sea grows dangerous,
How it spits against the clouds, how it capers,
And how the fiery element frights it back!
There be devils dancing in the air, I think
I saw a dolphin hang ith' horns of the moon
Shot from a wave: heigh day, heigh day,
How she kicks and yerks?
Down wi' the main mast, lay her at hull,
Farl up all her linens, and let her ride it out.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.l: She'll never brook it master.
She's so deep laden, that she'll bulge;

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: Hang her.
Can she not buffet with a storm a little?
How it tosses her! she reels like a drunkard.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor.
sp.l: We have discovered the land sir,
Pray let's make in, she's so drunk, else,
She may chance to cast up all her lading.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.p: Sland in, sland in, we are all lost else, lost and perished.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.l: Steer her a star board there.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor.
sp.l: Bear in with all the sail we can, see master
See, what a clap of thunder there is,
What a face of heaven, how dreadfully it looks?

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: Thou rascal, thou fearful rogue, thou hast been praying;
I see't in thy face, thou hast been mumbling,
When we are split you slave; is this a time,
To discourage our friends with your cold orisons?
Call up the boatswain; how it storms; holla.

sp.speaker: Boatswain.
sp.l: What shall we do master?
Cast over all her lading? she will not swim
An hour else;Enter Albert Franvile lamure Tibalt de pont. Morillat.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The storm is loud,
We cannot hear one another,
What's the coast?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: We know not yet; shall we make in?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: What comfort sailors?
I never saw, since I have known the sea,
(Which has been this twenty years) so rude a tempest.
In what state are we?

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: Dangerous enough captain,
We have sprung five leaks, and no little ones;
Still rage; besides her ribs are open;
Her rudder almost spent; prepare yourselves;
And have good courages, death comes but once,
And let him come in all his frights.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Is't not possible,
To make in toth' land? 'tis here before us.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: Here hard by sir.

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: Death is nearer gentlemen.
Yet do not cry, let's die like men.

sp.speaker: Talbat.
sp.l: Shall's hoist the boat out,Enter Amint.
And go all at one cast? the more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Master.
sp.l: You are too hasty monsieur,
Do ye long to be ith' fishmarket before your time?
Hold her up there.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O miserable fortune,
Nothing but horror sounding in mine ears,
No minute to promise to my frighted soul.

sp.speaker: Tibat.
sp.l: Peace woman,
We ha' storms enough already; no more howling.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Gentle master.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Clap this woman under hatches.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Prithee speak mildly to her.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Can no help?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: None that I know.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No promise from your goodness?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Am I a god? for heaven's sake stoaw this woman.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: Go: take your gilt prayer book;
And to your business; wink and die,
There an old haddock stays for ye.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Must I die here in all the frights, the terrors,
The thousand several shapes, death triumphs in?
No friend to council me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Have peace sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No kindred's tears upon me? Oh! my country!
No gentle hand to close mine eyes?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be comforted, heaven has the same
Power still, and the same mercy.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh! that wave will devour me!

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Carry her down captain;
Or by these hands, I'll give no more direction,
Let the ship sink or swim; we ha' never better luck,
When we ha' such stowage as these trinkets with us,
These sweet sin-breeders; how can heaven smile on us,
When such a burden of iniquity
Lies tumbling like a potion in our ships belly? Exit.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A way with her, and if she have a prayer,
That's fit for such an hour, let her say't quickly,
And seriously. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Come, I see it clear lady, come in,
And take some comfort. I'll stay with ye.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Where should I stay? to what end should I hope,
Am I not circled round with misery?
Confusions in their full heights dwell about me:
Oh monsieur Albert, how am I bound to curse ye,
If curses could redeem me? how to hate ye?
You forced me from my quiet, from my friends;
Even from their arms, that were as dear to me,
As day light is, or comfort to the wretched;
You forced my friends from their peaceful rest,
Some your relentless sword gave their last groans;
Would I had there been numbered;
And to fortunes never satisfied afflictions,
Ye turned my brother; and those few friends I'd left
Like desperate creatures, to their own fears
And the world's stubborn pities: o merciless.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: And whether they are wandered to avoid ye,
Or whether dead and no kind earth to cover 'em;
Was this a lover's part? but heaven has found ye,
And in his loud voice, his voice of thunder,
And in the mutiny of his deep wonders,
He tells ye now, ye weep too late:

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let these tears tell how I honour ye;
Ye know dear lady, since ye were mine,
How truly I have loved ye, how sanctimoniously
Observed your honour; not one lascivious word,
Not one touch lady; no, not a hope that might not render me
The unpolluted servant of your chastity;
For you I put to sea, to seek your brother;
Your captain, yet your slave, that his redemption,
If he be living, where the sun has circuit,
May expiate your rigor, and my rashness.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: The storm grows greater; what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let's in;
And ask heaven's mercy; my strong mind yet presages,
Through all these dangers, we shall see a day yetExit.
Shall crown your pious hopes, and my fair wishes.

div.stage: Enter master, Saylors, gentlemen, boatswain and surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: It must all over board.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: It clears to seaward mast.
Fling o'er the lading there, and let's lighten her;
All the meat, and the cakes, we are all gone else;
That we may find her leaks, and hold her up;
Yet save some little biscuit for the lady,
Till we come to the land.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Must my goods over too?
Why honest master? here lies all my money;
The money I ha' wracked by usury,
To buy new lands and lordships in new countries,
'Cause I was banished from mine own
I ha' been this twenty years a raising it.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: Out with it:
The devils are got together by the ears, who shall have it;
And here they quarrel in the clouds.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: I am undone sir:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: And be undone, 'tis better than we perish.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O save one chest of plate.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A way with it, lustily sailors;
It was some pawn, that he has got unjustly;
Down with it low enough, and let crabs breed in't;

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Over with the trunks too. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Take mine and spare not;

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We must over with all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye throw away my lordship
That I sold, put it into clothes and necessaries,
To go to sea with?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Over with it; I love to see a lordship sink;
Sir you left no wood upon't to bovy it up;
You might ha' saved it else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am undone for ever;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why we are all undone; would you be only happy?

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Sir you may lose too.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Thou liest; I ha' nothing but my skin,
And my clothes; my sword here, and myself;
Two crowns in my pocket; two pair of cards;
And three false dice: I can swim like a fish;
Rascal, nothing to hinder me.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: In with her of all hands.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, come captain, ye must help all;
My life now for the land,
'Tis high, and rocky, and full of perils;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: However let's attempt it.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Then cheer lustily my hearts. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Yes 'tis a ship, I see it now, a tall ship;
She has wrought lustily for her deliverance;
Heavens mercy, what a wretched day has here been?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: To still and quiet minds, that knew no misery,
It may seem wretched, but with us 'tis ordinary;
Heaven has no storm in store, nor earth no terror,
That can seem new to us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: 'Tis true Nicusa; if fortune were determined
To be wanton, and would wipe out the storeys
Of men's miseries: yet we two living,
We could cross her purpose; for 'tis impossible
She should cure us, we are so excellent in our afflictions;
It would be more than glory to her blindness,
And style her power beyond her pride, to quit us.

sp.speaker: Nicusa.
sp.l: Do they live still?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Yes, and make to harbour:

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Most miserable men; I grieve their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: How happy had they been, had the sea covered 'em?
They leap from one calamity to another;
Had they been drowned, they had ended all their sorrows.
What shouts of joy they make?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Alas poor wretches, had they but once experience
Of this island, they'd turn their tunes to wailings;

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Nay, to curses.
That ever they set foot on such calamities;
Here's nothing but rocks and barrenness,
Hunger, and cold to eat; here's no vineyards
To cheer the heart of man, no crystal rivers
After his labour to refresh his body,
If he be feeble; nothing to restore him,
But heavenly hopes; nature that made those remedies,
Dares not come here, nor look on our distresses,
For fear she turn wild like the place and barren.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: O uncle, yet a little memory of what we were,
'Twill be a little comfort in our calamities;
When we were seated in our blessed homes,
How happy in our kindreds, in our families,
In all our fortunes?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Curse on those French pirates, that displanted us;
That flung us from that happiness we found there;
Constrained us to sea, to save our lives, honours and our riches,
Withal we had, our kinsmen and our jewels,
In hope to find some place free from such robbers,
Where a mighty storm severed our barks,
That, where my wife, my daughter
And my noble ladies that went with her,
Virgins and loving souls, to scape those pirates.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.l: They are living yet; such goodness cannot perish.

sp.speaker: Sebast
sp.l: But never to me cousin;
Never to me again; what bears their flagstaffs?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: The arms of France sure;
Nay, do not start, we cannot be more miserable;
Death is a cordial, now, come when it will.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: They get to shore a pace, they'll fly as fast
When once they find the place; what's that which swims there?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: A strong young man sir, with a handsome woman.
Hanging about his neck.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: That shows some honour;
May thy brave charity whate'er thou art,
Be spoken in a place, that may renown thee,
And not die here.

sp.speaker: Nicasa.
sp.l: The boat it seems turned over,
So forced to their shifts, yet all are landed,
They're pirates on my life.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: They will not rob us;
For none will take our misery for riches:
Come cousin, let's descend and try their pities;
If we get off, a little hope walks with us;
If not, we shall but load this wretched island
With the same shadows still that must grow shorter. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Tibalt, Morillat La-mure, master, Franvile, surgeon, Saylors.

sp.speaker: Tibal.
sp.l: Wet come ashore my mates, we are safe arrived yet.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Thanks to heaven's goodness, no man lost;
The ship rides fair to, and her leaks in good plight.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: The weathers turned more courteous;
How does my dear?
Alas, how weak she is and wet?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I am glad yet, I scaped with life;
Which certain noble captain, next to heaven's goodness,
I must thank you for, and which is more,
Acknowledge your dear tenderness, your firm love
To your unworthy mistress, and recant to
(Indeed I must) those harsh opinions,
Those cruel unkind thoughts, I heaped upon ye;
Farther than that, I must forget your injuries.
So far I am tied, and fettered to your service,
Believe me I will learn to love.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: I thank ye madam,
And it shall be my practice to serve.
What cheer companions?

sp.speaker: Tibalt.
sp.l: No great cheer sir, a piece of soused biscuit
And half a hard egg; for the sea has taken order;
Being young and strong, we shall not surfeit captain.
For mine own part, I'll dance till I'm dry;
Come surgeon, out with your glister-pipe,
And strike a galliard.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What a brave day again;
And what fair weather, after so foul a storm?

sp.speaker: Lamure.
sp.l: I an't pleased the master, he might ha' seen
This weather, and ha' saved our goods.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Never think on 'em, we have our lives and healths.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: I must think on 'em, and think
'Twas most maliciously done to undo me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And me to, I lost all;
I han't another shirt to put upon me, nor clothes
But these poor rags; I had fifteen fair suits,
The worst was cut upon taffety.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am glad you ha' lost, give me thy hand,
Is thy skin whole? art thou not purled with scabs?
No ancient monuments of madam Venus?
Thou hast a suit then will pose the cunningest tailor,
That will never turn fashion, nor forsake thee,
Till thy executors the worms uncase thee,
They take off glorious suits Franvile: thou art happy,
Thou art delivered of 'em; here are no brokers;
No alchemists to turn 'em into mettle;
Nor leathered captains with ladies to adore 'em;
Wilt thou see a dogfish rise in one of thy brave doublets,
And tumble like a tub to make thee merry,
Or an old haddock rise with thy hatched sword
Thou paid'st a hundred crowns for?
A mermaid in a mantle of your worships,
Or a dolphin in your double ruff?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye are merry, but if I take it thus,
If I be foisted and jeered out of my goods.

sp.speaker: Lamure.
sp.l: Nor I, I vow thee.
Nor master nor mate, I see your cunning,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O be not angry gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Moril.
sp.l: Yes sir we have reason.
And some friends I can make.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: What I did gentlemen, was for the general safety.
If ye aim at me, I am not so tame.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Pray take my council gallants.
Fight not till the surgeon be well,
He's damnable sea-sick, and may spoil all;
Besides he has lost his fiddlestick, and the best
Box of boar's grease; why do you make such faces,
And hand your swords?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who would ye fight with? Gentlemen?
Who has done ye wrong? for shame be better tempered.
No sooner come to give thanks for our safeties,
But we must raise new civil broils amongst us
Inflame those angry powers, to shower new vengeance on us?
What can we expect for these unmanly murmurs,
These strong temptations of their holy pities,
But plagues in another kind, a fuller, so dreadful,
That the singing storms are slumbers to it?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Be men and rule your minds;
If you will needs fight gentlemen,
And think to raise new riches by your valours,
Have at ye, I have little else to do now
I have said my prayers; you say you have lost,
And make your loss your quarrel,
And grumble at my captain here, and the master,
Two worthy persons; indeed too worthy for such rascals,
Thou galloone gallant, and Mammon you
That build on golden mountains, thou money maggot;
Come all draw your swords, ye say ye are miserable.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, hold good Tibalt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captain, let me correct 'em;
I'll make ye ten times worse, I will not leave 'em;
For look ye, fighting is as nourishing to me as eating,
I was born quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I will not leave 'em skins to cover 'em;
Do ye grumble, when ye are well ye rogues?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Noble Dupont.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ye have clothes now: and ye prate.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen, for my sake be at peace.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Let it become me to make all friends.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have stopped our angers lady.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This shows noble.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: 'Tis well: 'tis very well: there's half a biscuit,
Break't amongst ye all, and thank my bounty,
This is clothes and plate too; come no more quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But ha! what things are these,Enter Sebastian and Nicusa.
Are they humane creatures?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I have heard of sea-calves.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are no shadows sure, they have legs and arms.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: They hang but lightly on though.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: How they look, are they men's faces?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: They have horsetails growing to 'em,
Goodly long manes.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Alas what sunk eyes they have!
How they are crept in, as if they had been frighted!
Sure they are wretched men.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Where are their wardrobes?
Look ye Franvile, here are a couple of courtiers.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: They kneel, alas poor souls.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What are ye? speak; are ye alive,
Or wand'ring shadows, that find no peace on earth,
Till ye reveal some hidden secret?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: We are men as you are;
Only our miseries make us seem monsters.
If ever pity dwelled in noble hearts;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We understand 'em too: pray mark 'em gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Sebast,
sp.l: Or that heaven is pleased with human charity;
If ever ye have heard the name of friendship?
Or suffered in yourselves, the least afflictions,
Have gentle fathers that have bred ye tenderly,
And mothers that have wept for your misfortunes,
Have mercy on our miseries.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stand up wretches;
Speak boldly, and have release;

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.l: If ye be Christians,
And by that blessed name, bound to relieve us,
Convey us from this island.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Speak; what are ye?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: As you are, gentle born; to tell ye more,
Were but to number up our own calamities,
And turn your eyes wild with perpetual weepings;
These many years, in this most wretched island
We two have lived: the scorn and game of fortune;
Bless yourselves from it noble gentlemen;
The greatest plagues, that humane nature suffers,
Are seated here, wildness, and wants innumerable.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How came ye hither?

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.l: In a ship, as you do, and as you might have been.
Had not heaven preserved ye for some more noble use;
Wracked desperately; our men, and all consumed,
But we two; that still live, and spin out
The thin and ragged threads of our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Is there no meat above?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Nor meat nor quiet;
No summer here, to promise any thing;
Nor autumn, to make full the reapers hands;
The earth obdurate to the tears of heaven,
Let's nothing shoot but poisoned weeds.
No rivers, nor no pleasant groves, no beasts;
All that were made for man's use, fly this desert;
No aery fowl dares makes his flight over it,
It is so ominous.
Serpents, and ugly things, the shames of nature,
Roots of malignant tastes, foul standing waters;
Sometimes we find a fulsome sea-root,
And that's a delicate: a rat sometimes,
And that we hunt like princes in their pleasure;
And when we take a toad, we make a banquet.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: For heaven's sake let's aboard.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: D'ye know no farther?

sp.speaker: Nicusa.
sp.l: Yes, we have sometimes seen the shadow of a place inhabited;
And heard the noise of hunters;
And have attempted to find it, so far as a river,
Deep, slow, and dangerous, fenced with high rocks,
We have gone; but not able to achieve that hazard,
Return to our old miseries.
If this sad story, may deserve your pities,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye shall aboard with us, we will relieve your miseries:

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Nor will we be unthankful for this benefit;
No gentlemen, we'll pay for our deliverance;
Look ye that plough the seas for wealth and pleasures,
That outrun day and night with your ambitions,
Look on those heaps, they seem hard ragged quarries;
Remove 'em, and view 'em fully.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: O heaven, they are gold and jewels.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Be not too hasty, here lies another heap.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: And here another
All perfect gold.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stand farther off, you must not be your own carvers;

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: We have shares, and deep ones;

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes sir, we'll maintain't: ho fellow sailors.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Stand all to your freedoms;
I'll have all this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I this.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You shall be hanged first.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: My losses shall be made good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So shall mine, or with my sword I'll do't;
All that will share with us, assist us.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captain let's set in.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This money will undo us, undo us all:

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: This gold was the overthrow of my happiness;
I had command too, when I landed here,
And lead young, high, and noble spirits under me,
This cursed gold enticing 'em, they set upon their captain,
On me that own this wealth, and this poor gentleman,
Gave us no few wounds, forced us from our own;
And then their civil swords, who should be owners,
And who lords over all, turned against their own lives,
First in their rage consumed the ship,
That poor part of the ship that 'scaped the first wrack,
Next their lives by heaps; oh be you wise and careful:

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: We'll ha' more: sirrah, come show it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or ten times worse afflictions than thou speak'st of.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, and ye will be dogs.Beats 'em out.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Let me come captain:
This golden age must have an iron ending.
Have at the bunch.He beats 'em off. Exit.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: O Albert; oh gentlemen; oh friends. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Come noble nephew, if we stay here, we die,
Here rides their ship, yet all are gone toth' spoil,
Let's make a quick use.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.l: Away dear uncle.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: This gold was our overthrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: It may now be our happiness. Enter Tibalt and the rest.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You shall have gold: yes, I'll cram it int'ee;
You shall be your own carvers; yes, I'll carve ye.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: I am sore, I pray hear reason:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I'll hear none.
Covetous base minds have no reason;
I am hurt myself; but whilst I have a leg left,
I will so haunt your guilded souls; how d'ye captain?
Ye bleed apace, curse on the causers on't;
Ye do not faint?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No, no; I am not so happy.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: D'ye howl, nay, ye deserve it:
Base greedy rogues; come, shall we make an end of 'em?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are our countrymen, for heaven's sake spare 'em,
Alas, they are hurt enough: and they relent now. Aminta above.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O captain, captain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Whose voice is that?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The ladies.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Look captain, look; ye are undone: poor captain,
We are all undone: all, all: we are all miserable,
Mad wilful men; ye are undone, your ship, your ship.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: She's under sail and floating;
See where she flies: see to your shames, you wretches:
Those poor starved things, that showed you gold. La-m. and Franvile goes up to see the ship.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.l: They have cut the cables,
And got her out; the tide too has befriended 'em.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Where are the sailors that kept her?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Here, here in the mutiny, to take up money,
And left no creature, left the boat ashore too;
This gold, this damned enticing gold.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor.
sp.l: How the wind drives her,
As if it vied to force her from our furies?

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Come back good old men:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good honest men, come back.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The winds against ye, speak louder;

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Ye shall have all your gold again: they see us.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hold up your hands, and kneel,
And howl ye blockheads; they'll have compassion on ye;
Yes, yes, 'tis very likely: ye have deserved it,
D'ye look like dogs now?
Are your mighty courages abated?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I bleed apace Tibalt:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Retire sir; and make the best use of our miseries.
They but begin now. Enter Aminta;

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Are ye alive still?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yes sweet.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Help him off lady;
And wrap him warm, in your arms,
Here's something that's comfortable; off with him handsomely,
I'll come to ye straight: but vex these rascals a little. Exit Albert Aminta.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh! I am hungry, and hurt, and I am weary.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here's a pestle of a portigue, sir;
'Tis excellent meat, with sour sauce;
And here's two chains, suppose 'em sausages;
Then there wants mustard.
But the fearful surgeon will supply ye presently:

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O for that surgeon, I shall die else.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Faith, there he lies in the same pickle too.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: My salves, and all my instruments are lost;
And I am hurt, and starved;
Good sir, seek for some herbs.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here's herb graceless; will that serve?
Gentlemen, will ye go to supper!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Where's the meat?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Where's the meat? what a veal voice is there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Would we had it sir, or any thing else;

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I would now cut your throat you dog,
But that I woe not do you such a courtesy;
To take you from the benefit of starving.
O! what a comfort will your worship have, some three days hence?
Yea things beneath pity shall be your harbinger;
You must not look for down-beds here,
Nor hangings; though I could wish ye strong on's;
Yet here be many lightsome cool star-chambers,
Open to every sweet air, I'll assure ye,
Ready provided for ye, and so I'll leave ye;
Your first course is served, expect the second. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A vengeance on these jewels.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O! this cursed gold. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Alas, dear soul ye faint.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: You speak the language
Which I should use to you; heaven knows, my weakness
Is not for what I suffer in myself,
But to imagine what you endure, and to what fate
Your cruel stars reserve ye.

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.l: Do not add to my afflictions
By your tender pities; sure we have changed sexes;
You bear calamity with a fortitude
Would become a man; I like a weak girl suffer.

sp.speaker: Amint
sp.l: O! but your wounds,
How fearfully they gape? and every one
To me is a sepulchre; if I loved truly,
Wise men affirm that true love can do wonders,
This bathed in my warm tears, would soon be cured,
And leave no orifice behind; pray give me leave
To play the surgeon, and bind 'em up;
The raw air rankles 'em.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet, we want means.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Love can supply all wants.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What have ye done sweet?
O sacrilege to beauty: there's no hair
Of these pure locks, by which the greatest King
Would not be gladly bound, and love his fetters.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O Albert, I offer this sacrifice of service
To the altar of your staid temperance, and still adore it;
When with a violent hand you made me yours,
I cursed the doer: but now I consider,
How long I was in your power? and with what honour
You entertained me? it being seldom seen,
That youth and heat of blood could ere prescribe
Laws to itself; your goodness is the Lethe,
In which I drown your injuries, and now live
Truly to serve ye: how do you sir?
Receive you the least ease from my service?
If you do, I am largely recompensed.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You good angels,
That are engaged, when man's ability fails,
To reward goodness: look upon this lady
Though hunger gripes my croaking entrails,
Yet when I kiss these rubies, methinks
I'm at a banquet a refreshing banquet;
Speak my blesse't one art not hungry?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Indeed I could eat, to bear you company.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Blush unkind nature,
If thou hast power: or being to hear
Thyself, and by such innocence accused;
Must print a thousand kinds of shames, upon
Thy various face: canst thou supply a drunkard,
And with a prodigal hand, reach choice of wines,
Till he cast up thy blessings? or a glutton,
That robs the elements, to soothe his palate,
And only eats to beget appetite,
Not to be satisfied? and suffer here
A virgin, which the saints would make their guest,
To pine for hunger? ha, if my senseHorns within.
Deceive me not, these notes take being
From the breath of men; confirm me my Aminta;
Again, this way the gentle wind conveys it to us,
Hear you nothing?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Yes, it seems free hunter's music;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Still 'tis louder; and I remember the Portugals
Informed us, they had often heard such sounds,
But never could touch the shore from whence it came;
Follow me, my Aminta: my good genius,
Show me the way still; still we are directed;
When we gain the top of this near rising hillExit. and enter above.
We shall know further.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Courteous Zephyrus
On his dewy wings, carries perfumes to cheer us;
The air clears too;
And now, we may discern another island,
And questionless, the seat of fortunate men:
Oh that we could arrive there;

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No Albert, 'tis not to be hoped;
This envious torrent's cruelly interposed;
We have no vessel that may transport us;
Nor hath nature given us wings to fly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Better try all hazards,
Then perish here remediless; I feel
New vigour in me, and a spirit that dares
More than a man, to serve my fair Aminta;
These arms shall be my oars, with which I'll swim;
And my zeal to save thy innocent self,
Like wings, shall bear me up above the brackish waves.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Well ye then leave me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Till now I ne'er was wretched.
My best Aminta, I swear by goodness
'Tis nor hope, nor fear, of myself, that invites me
To this extreme; 'tis to supply thy wants; and believe me
Though pleasure met me in most ravishing forms,
And happiness courted me to entertain her,
I would nor eat nor sleep till I returned
And crowned thee with my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O but your absence.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Suppose it but a dream; and as you may,
Endeavour to take rest; and when that sleep
Deceives your hunger with imagined food,
Think you have sent me for discovery
Of some most fortunate continent, yet unknown,
Which you are to be Queen of.
And now ye powers that ere heard lovers prayers,
Or cherished pure affection, look on him
That is your votary; and make it known
Against all stops, you can defend your own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How did we lose Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: When we believed the stag was spent, and would take soil,
The sight of the black lake which we supposed
He chose for his last refuge, frighted him more
Than we that did pursue him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That's usual; for, death itself is not so terrible
To any beast of chase.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Since we lived here, we ne'er could force one to it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: 'Tis so dreadful,
Birds that with their pinions cleave the air
Dare not fly over it: when the stag turned head,
And we even tired with labour, Clarinda, as if
She were made of air and fire,
And had no part of earth in her, eagerly pursued him;
Nor need we fear her safety, this place yields not
Fawns nor satires, or more lustful men;
Here we live secure,
And have among ourselves a commonwealth,
Which in ourselves begun, with us must end.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I there's the misery.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: But being alone,
Allow me freedom but to speak my thoughts;
The strictness of our governess, that forbids us
On pain of death the sight and use of men,
Is more than tyranny: for herself, she's passed
Those youthful heats, and feels not the want
Of that which young maids long for: and her daughter
The fair Clarinda, though in few years
Improved in height and large proportion,
Came here so young,
That scarce remembering that she had a father,
She never dreams of man; and should she see one,
In my opinion, 'a would appear a strange beast to her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not so with us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: For my part, I confess it, I was not made
For this single life; nor do I love hunting so,
But that I had rather be the chase myself.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: By Venus (Out upon me) I should have sworn
By Diana, I am of thy mind too wench;
And though I have ta'en an oath, not alone
To detest, but never to think of man,
Every hour something tells me I am forsworn;
For I confess imagination helps me sometimes,
And that's all is left for us to feed on,
We might starve else; for if I have any pleasure
In this life, but when I sleep, I am a pagan;
Then from the courtier to the country clown,
I have strange visions.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Visions crocale?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Yes, and fine visions too;
And visions I hope in dreams are harmless,
And not forbid by our canons; the last night
(Troth 'tis a foolish one, but I must tell it)
As I lay in my cabin betwixt sleeping and waking,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Upon your back?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: How should a young maid lie, fool,
When she would be entranced?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We are instructed; forward I prithee.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Methought a sweet young man
In years, some twenty, with a downy chin,
Promising a future beard, and yet no red one,
Stole slyly to my cabin, all unbraced,
Took me in his arms, and kissed me twenty times,
Yet still I slept.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fie; thy lips run over crocale.
But to the rest.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Lord, what a man is this thought I,
To do this to a maid!
Yet then for my life I could not wake.
The youth, a little daunted, with a trembling hand
Heaved up the clothes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yet still you slept.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I'faith I did; and when, methought, he was warm by my side,
Thinking to catch him, I stretched out both mine arms;
And when I felt him not, I shrieked out,
And waked for anger.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Twas a pretty dream. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Ay, if it had been a true one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But stay, what's here cast oth' shore?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis a man;
Shall I shoot him?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis a handsome beast;
Would we had more o'the breed; stand close wenches,
And let's hear if he can speak.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do I yet live?
Sure it is air I breathe; what place is this?
Sure something more than humane keeps residence here,
For I have passed the Stygian gulf,
And touch upon the blessed shore? 'tis so;
This is the Elysian shade; these happy spirits,
That here enjoy all pleasures.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He makes towards us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand, or I'll shoot.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Hold, he makes no resistance.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be not offended goddesses, that I fall
Thus prostrate at your feet: or if not such,
But nymphs of Dian's train, that range these groves,
Which you forbid to men; vouchsafe to know
I am a man, a wicked sinful man; and yet not sold
So far to impudence, as to presume
To press upon your privacies, or provoke
Your heavenly angers; 'tis not for myself
I beg thus poorly, for I am already wounded,
Wounded to death, and faint; my last breath
Is for a virgin comes as near yourselves
In all perfection, as what's mortal may
Resemble things divine. O pity her,
And let your charity free her from that desert,
If heavenly charity can reach to hell,
For sure that place comes near it: and where ere
My ghost shall find abode,
Eternally I shall pour blessings on ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By my life I can not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Though I lose my head for it, nor I. Enter Clarinda.
I must pity him and will.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But stay, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What new game have ye found here, ha!
What beast is this lies wallowing in his gore?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Keep off.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Wherefore, I pray? I ne'er turned
From a fell lioness robbed of her whelps,
And shall I fear dead carrion?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O but.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But, what is't?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is infectious.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Has it not a name?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Yes, but such a name from which
As from the devil your mother commands us fly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is it a man?

sp.speaker: Cro
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What a brave shape it has in death;
How excellent would it appear had it life!
Why should it be infectious? I have heard
My mother say I had a father,
And was not he a man?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Questionless madam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your fathers too were men?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Without doubt lady.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And without such it is impossible
We could have been.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A sin against nature to deny it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor can you or I have any hope to be a mother
Without the help of men.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Which of you then most barbarous, that knew
You from a man had being, and owe to it
The name of parent, durst presume to kill
The likeness of that thing by which you are?
Whose arrows made these wounds? speak, or by Dian
Without distinction I'll let fly at ye all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not mine.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: 'Tis strange to see her moved thus.
Restrain your fury madam; had we killed him,
We had but performed your mother's command.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But if she command unjust and cruel things,
We are not to obey it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: We are innocent; some storm did cast
Him shipwrecked on the shore, as you see, wounded:
Nor durst we be surgeons to such
Your mother doth appoint for death.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Weak excuse; where's pity?
Where's soft compassion? cruel, and ungrateful!
Did providence offer to your charity
But one poor subject to express it on,
And in't to show our wants too; and could you
So carelessly neglect it?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: For ought I know, he's living yet;
And you may tempt your mother, by giving him succour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ha, come near I charge ye.
So, bend his body softly; rub his temples;
Nay, that shall be my office: how the red
Steals into his pale lips! run and fetch the simples
With which my mother healed my arm
When last I was wounded by the boar.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Do: but remember her to come after ye,
That she may behold her daughter's charity.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Now he breathes;Exit Hippolita.
The air passing through the Arabian groves
Yields not so sweet an odour: prithee taste it;
Taste it good crocale; yet I envy thee so great a blessing;
'Tis not sin to touch these rubies, is it?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not, I think.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Or thus to live chameleon like?
I could resign my essence to live ever thus.
O welcome; raise him up gently. Some soft hand
Bound up these wounds; a woman's hair. What fury
For which my ignorance does not know a name,
Is crept into my bosom? But I forgetEnter Hipolita.
My pious work. Now if this juice hath power,
Let it appear; his eyelids ope: prodigious!
Two suns break from these orbs.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ha, where am I? what new vision's this?
To what goddess do I owe this second life?
Sure thou art more than mortal:
And any sacrifice of thanks or duty
In poor and wretched man to pay, comes short
Of your immortal bounty: but to show
I am not unthankful, thus in humility
I kiss the happy ground you have made sacred
By bearing of your weight.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No goddess, friend: but made
Of that same brittle mould as you are;
One too acquainted with calamities,
And from that apt to pity. Charity ever
Finds in the act reward, and needs no trumpet
In the receiver. O forbear this duty;
I have a hand to meet with yours,
And lips to bid yours welcome.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I see, that by instinct.
Though a young maid hath never seen a man,
Touches have titulations, and inform her. Enter Rosella.
But here's our governess;
Now I expect a storm.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Child of my flesh,
And not of my fair unspotted mind,
Unhand this monster.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Monster, mother?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes; and every word he speaks, a Siren's note,
To drown the careless hearer. Have I not taught thee
The falsehood and the perjuries of men?
On whom, but for a woman to show pity,
Is to be cruel to herself; the sovereignty
Proud and imperious men usurp upon us,
We confer on ourselves, and love those fetters
We fasten to our freedoms. Have we, Clarinda,
Since thy father's wrack, sought liberty,
To lose it uncompelled? did fortune guide,
Or rather destiny, our bark, to which
We could appoint no port, to this blessed place,
Inhabited heretofore by warlike women,
That kept men in subjection? did we then
By their example, after we had lost
All we could love in man, here plant ourselves,
With execrable oaths never to look
On man, but as a monster? and wilt thou
Be the first precedent to infringe those vows
We made to heaven?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hear me; and hear me with justice.
And as ye are delighted in the name
Of mother, hear a daughter that would be like you.
Should all women use this obstinate abstinence,
You would force upon us; in a few years
The whole world would be peopled
Only with beasts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We must and will have men.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I or we'll shake off all obedience.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Are ye mad?
Can no persuasion alter ye? suppose
You had my suffrage to your suit;
Can this shipwrecked wretch supply them all?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hear me great lady?
I have fellows in my misery, not far hence,
Divided only by this hellish river,
There live a company of wretched men
Such as your charity may make your slaves;
Imagine all the miseries mankind
May suffer under: and they groan beneath 'em.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But are they like to you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Speak they your language?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Are they able, lusty men?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They were good ladies;
And in their may of youth of gentle blood,
And such as may deserve ye; now cold and hunger
Hath lessened their perfection: but restored
To what they were, I doubt not they'll appear
Worthy your favours.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is a blessing
We durst not hope for.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dear mother, be not obdurate.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Hear then my resolution: and labour not
To add to what I'll grant, for 'twill be fruitless,
You shall appear as good angels to these wretched men;
In a small boat we'll pass o'er to 'em;
And bring 'em comfort: if you like their persons,
And they approve of yours: for we'll force nothing;
And since we want ceremonies,
Each one shall choose a husband, and enjoy
His company a month, but that expired
You shall no more come near 'em; if you prove fruitful,
The males ye shall return to them, the females
We will reserve ourselves: this is the utmost,
Ye shall 'Ere obtain: as ye think fit;
Ye may dismiss this stranger,
And prepare tomorrow for the journey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come sir, will ye walk?
We will show ye our pleasant bowers,
And something ye shall find to cheer your heart.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent lady;
Though 'twill appear a wonder one near starved
Should refuse rest and meat, I must not take
Your noble offer: I left in yonder desert
A virgin almost pinned.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: She's not your wife?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No lady, but my sister ('tis now dangerous
To speak truth) to her I deeply vowed
Not to taste food or rest, if fortune brought it me,
Till I blessed her with my return: now if you please
To afford me an easy passage to her,
And some meat for her recovery,
I shall live your slave: and thankfully
She shall ever acknowledge her life at your service.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You plead so well, I can deny ye nothing;
I myself will see you furnished;
And with the next sun visit and relieve thee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are all goodness Exit.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Oh! what a tempest have I in my stomach?
How my empty guts cry out? my wounds ache,
Would they would bleed again, that I might get
Something to quench my thirst.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Lamure, the happiness my dogs had
When I kept house at home! they had a storehouse,
A storehouse of most blessed bones and crusts,
Happy crusts: oh! how sharp hunger pinches me? Exit Franvile

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O my importunate belly I have nothing
To satisfy thee; I have sought,
As far as my weak legs would carry me,
Yet can find nothing: neither meat nor water;
Nor any thing that's nourishing,
My bellies grown together like an empty satchel. Enter Franvile.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How now what news?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hast any meat yet?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not a bit that I can see;
Here be goodly quarries, but they be cruel hard
To gnaw: I ha' got some mud, we'll eat it with spoons,
Very good thick mud: but it stinks damnably;
There's old rotten trunks of trees to,
But not a leaf nor blossom in all the island.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How it looks?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: It stinks too.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: It may be poison.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let it be any thing;
So I can get it down: why man,
Poison's a princely dish.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hast thou no biscuit?
No crumbs left in thy pocket: here's my doublet,
Give me but three small crumbs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not for three kingdoms,
If I were master of 'em: o Lamure,
But one poor joint of mutton: we ha' scorned (Man)

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou speakest of paradise,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or but the snuffs of those healths,
We have lewdly at midnight flang away.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ah! but to lick the glasses. En. surgeon

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here comes the surgeon: what
Hast thou discovered? smile, smile, and comfort us.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I am expiring;
Smile they that can: I can find nothing gentlemen,
Here's nothing can be meat without a miracle.
O that I had my boxes and my lints now,
My stupes, my tents, and those sweet helps of nature,
What dainty dishes could I make of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hast near an old suppository?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: O would I had sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Or, but the paper where such a cordial
Potion or pills hath been entombed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or, the blessed bladder where a cooling glister

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hast thou no searcloths left?
Nor any old poulties?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We care not to what it hath been ministered.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Sure I have none of these dainties gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where's the great wen
Thou cutst from Hugh the sailors shoulder?
That would serve now for a most princely banquet.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Ay, if we had it gentlemen.
I flung it overboard, slave that I was;

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A most unprovident villain.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: If I had any thing that were but supple now!
I could make salads of your shoes gentlemen,
And rare ones: any thing unctuous.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I and then we might fry the soles ith' sun.
The soles would make a second dish.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Or, souse 'em in the salt-water,
An inner sole well soused. En. Aminta

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here comes the woman;
It may be she has meat and may relieve us,
Let's withdraw, and mark and then be ready,
She'll hide her store else, and so cozen us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How weary and how hungry am I,
How feeble and how faint is all my body?
Mine eyes like spent lamps glowing out grow heavy,
My sight forsaking me and all my spirits,
As if they heard my passing bell go for me,
Pull in their powers and give me up to destiny,
Oh! for a little water: a little little meat,
A little to relieve me ere I perish:
I had whole floods of tears awhile that nourished me,
But they are all consumed for thee dear Albert;
For thee they are spent, for thou art dead;
Merciless fate hath swallowed thee.
O I grow heavy: sleep is a salve for misery;
Heaven look on me, and either take my life,
Or make me once more happy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He's fast asleep already,
Why should she have this blessing, and we wake still,
Wake to our wants?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: This thing hath been our overthrow,
And all these biting mischiefs that fall on us
Are come through her means.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: True we were bound ye all know,
For happy places and most fertile islands,
Where we had constant promises of all things,
She turned the captain's mind,
And must have him go in search, I know not of who,
Nor to what end: of such a fool her brother,
And such a coxcomb her kinsman, and we must put in everywhere ,
She has put us in now i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why should we consume thus, and starve,
Have nothing to relieve us;
And she live there that bred all our miseries,
Unroast or unsod?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I have read in storeys.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Of such restoring meats,
We have examples;
Thousand examples and allowed for excellent;
Women that have eat their children,
Men their slaves, nay their brothers: but these are nothing;
Husbands devoured their wives (They are their chattels,)
And of a schoolmaster that in a time of famine,
Powdered up all his scholars.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: She's young and tidy,
In my conscience she'll eat delicately;
Just like young pork a little lean,
Your opinion surgeon.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I think she may be made good meat.
But look we shall want salt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tush, she needs no powdering,

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I grant ye;
But to suck out the humorous parts: by all means,
Let's kill her in a chafe, she'll eat the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Let's kill her any way: and kill her quickly,
That we might be at our meat.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: How if the captain?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Talk not of him, he's dead, and the rest famished.
Wake her surgeon, and cut her throat,
And then divide her, every man his share.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She wakes herself.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Holy and good things keep me!
What cruel dreams have I had! who are these?
O they are my friends; for heaven's sake gentlemen
Give me some food to save my life: if ye have ought to spare;
A little to relieve me: I may bless ye;
For weak and wretched, ready to perish
Even now I die.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You'll save a labour then,
You bred these miseries, and you shall pay for't;
We have no meat, nor where to have we know not,
Nor how to pull ourselves from these afflictions,
We are starved too, famished, all our hopes deluded;
Yet ere we die thus, we'll have one dainty meal.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Shall I be with ye gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes marry shall ye: in our bellies lady.
We love you well

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: What said you sir?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Marry we'll eat your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You that have buried us in this base island,
We'll bury ye in a more noble monument.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Will ye say your prayers, that I may perform lady?
We are wondrous sharp set; come gentlemen,
Who are for the hinder parts?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I. Fran. I.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Be patient;
They will not fall to every man's share.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O hear me;
Hear me ye barbarous men.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Be short and pithy,
Our stomachs cannot stay a long discourse.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: And be not fearful,
For I'll kill ye daintily.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Are ye not Christians?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Why, do not Christians eat women? En. Tibalt master, Saylors.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Eat one another? 'tis most impious.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Come come.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O, help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The lady's voice! stand off slaves,
What do you intend villains?
I have strength enough left me, if you abuse this soul,
To

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They would have ravished her upon my life,
Speak, how was it lady?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Forgive 'em, 'twas their hungers.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ha, their hungers!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They would have eaten her.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O damned villains; speak, is it true?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I confess an appetite.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: An appetite, I'll fit ye for an appetite.
Are ye so sharp set that her flesh must serve you?
Murder's a main good service with your worships;
Since ye would be such devils,
Why did you not begin with one another handsomely;
And spare the woman to beget more food on?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You shall grow mumey rascals;
I'll make you fall to your brawns and your buttocks,
And worry one another like keen bandogs.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Good sir be merciful.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You shall know what 'tis to be damned cannibals.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my best friend! Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Alas poor heart! here,
Here's some meat and sovereign drink to ease you,
Sit down gentle sweet.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am blessed to see you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sir, not within forty foot of this food,
If you do dogs!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O, captain captain, captain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye shall have meat all of you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captain, hear me first: hark,
'Tis so inhumane! I would not ha' the air corrupted with it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O barbarous men! sit down Dupont,
Good master and honest sailors.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: But stand you off,
And wait upon our charity; I'll wait on you else;
And touch nothing but what's flung t'ee; as if you were dogs;
If you do, I'll cut your fingers; friends
I'll spoil your carving.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: There wretches there.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Eat your meat handsomely now,
And give heaven thanks.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There's more bread.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: See they snarl like dogs;
Eat quietly you rascals, eat quietly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There is drink too.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Come, come, I'll fill you each your cups,
Ye shall not surfeit.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: And what have you discovered?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet, a paradise,
A paradise inhabited with angels,
Such as you are: their pities made 'em angels,
They gave me these viands, and supplied me
With these precious drinks.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Shall not we see 'em?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yes, they will see you
Out of their charities, having heard our story
They will come, and comfort us, come presently
We shall no more know wants nor miseries.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Are they all women?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All, and all in love with us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do not mistake: in love with our misfortunes,
They will cherish and relieve our men.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Do you shrug now,
And pull up your noses? you smell comfort,
See they stretch out their legs, like dotterels,
Each like a new saint Dennis.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Dear mistress,
When you would name me, and the women hear,
Call me your brother, you I'll call my sister,
And pray observe this all
Why do you change colour sweet.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Eating too much meat.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sauce with jealousy;
Fie, fie dear saint, i'faith ye are too blame,En. Rossellia, Clarinda, crocale, Hipollitta Juletta.
Are ye not here? here fixed in my heart?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hark, hark;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are come, stand ready, and look nobly,
And with all humble reverence receive 'em,
Our lives depend upon their gentle pities,
And death waits on their anger.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Sure they are fairies.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Be they devils: devils of flesh and blood;
After so long a lent, and tedious voyage
To me they are angels.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O for some eringoes!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Potatoes, or cantharides.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Peace you rogues that buy abilities of your pothecaries,
Had I but took the diet of green cheese,
And onions for a month, I could do wonders.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Are these the jewels you run mad for?
What can you see in one of these
To whom you would vouchsafe a gentle touch?
Can nothing persuade you
To love yourselves, and place your happiness
In cold and chaste embraces of each other.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: This is from the purpose.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We had your grant to have them as they were.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis a beauteous creature,
And to myself, I do appear deformed,
When I consider her, and yet she is
The stranger's sister; why then should I fear?
She cannot prove my rival.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: When you repent,
That you refused my council, may it add
To your afflictions, that you were forward;
Yet leaped into the gulf of your misfortunes,
But have your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now she makes to us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am instructed, but take heed Albert,
You prove not false;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are your own assurance,
And so acquainted with your own perfections,
That weak doubts cannot reach you; therefore fear not.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: That you are poor and miserable men,
My eyes inform me: that without our succours,
Hope cannot flatter you to dream of safety;
The present plight you are in, can resolve you
That to be merciful, is to draw near
The heavenly essence: whether you will be
Thankful, I do not question; nor demand
What country bred you, what names, what manners;
To us it is sufficient we relieve
Such as have shapes of men: and I command you,
As we are not ambitious to know
Farther of you, that on pain of death
You presume not to inquire what we are
Or whence derived.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: In all things we obey you,
And thankfully we ever shall confess
Ourselves your creatures.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You speak as becomes you;
First then and willingly deliver up
Those weapons we could force from you

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We lay 'em down
Most gladly art your feet.

sp.speaker: Tih.
sp.l: I have had many a combat with a tall wench;
But never was disarmed before.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And now hear comfort,
Your wants shall be supplied, and though it be
A debt women may challenge to be sued to,
Especially from such they may command;
We give up to you that power, and therefore
Freely each make his choice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then here I fix.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay, she is mine: I eyed her first.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: This mine.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Stay good rascals;
You are too forward, sir gallant,
You are not giving order to a tailor
For the fashion of a new suit;
Nor are you in your warehouse, master merchant,
Stand back and give your betters leave: your betters;
And grumble not; if ye do, as I love meat
I will so swinge the salt itch out on you.
Captain, master and the rest of us,
That are brothers and good fellows: we have been
Too late by the ears: and yet smart for our follies;
To end therefore all future emulation: if you please,
To trust to my election, you shall say,
I am not partial to myself; I doubt not
Give content to all.

sp.speaker: All,
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then but observe how learned and discreetly,
I will proceed, and as a skilful doctor
In all the quirks belonging to the game;
Read over your complexions: for you captain
Beinst first in place and therefore first to be served,
I give my judgement thus, for your aspect
You're much inclined to melancholy: and that tells me
The sullen Saturn had predominance
At your nativity, a malignant planet,
And if not qualified by a sweet conjunction
Of a soft and ruddy wench born under Venus,
It may prove fatal: therefore to your arms,
I give this rose-cheeked virgin.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To my wish;
Till now I never was happy.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Nor I accursed.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Master, you are old;
Yet love the game, that I perceive too,
And if not well spurred up, you may prove rusty;
Therefore to help ye here's a Bradamanta,
Or I am cozened in my calculation.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: A poor old man allotted to my share.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Thou wouldst have two;
Nay I think twenty: but fear not wench,
Though he be old he's tough: look on's making,
He'll not fail I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A merry fellow,
And were not man a creature I detest,
I could endure his company.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Here's a fair heard of does before me,
And now for a barren one:
For though I like the sport: I do not love
To father children: like the grand signior,
Thus I walk in my seraglio,
And view 'em as I pass: then draw I forth
My handkercher, and having made my choice,
I thus bestow it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: On me.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: On you: now my choice is made;
To it you hungry rascals.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: As I love goodness,
It makes me smile ith' height of all my fears.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What a strong contention you may behold
Between my mother's mirth and anger.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Nay, no coyness: be mistress of your word,
I must and will enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Be advised fool: alas I am old;
How canst thou hope content from one that's fifty.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Never talk on't;
I have known good ones at threescore and upwards;
Besides the weathers hot: and men
That have experience, fear fevers:
A temperate diet is the only physic,
Your julips nor gujacum prunelloes,
Champhire pills, nor gourd-water,
Come not near your old woman;
Youthful stomachs are still craving,
Though their be nothing left to stop their mouths with;
And believe me I am no frequent giver of those bounties:
Laugh on: laugh on: good gentlemen do,
I shall make holiday and sleep, when you
Dig in the mines till your hearts ache.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A mad fellow;
Well sir, I'll give you hearing: and as I like
Your wooing and discourse: but I must tell ye sir,
That rich widows look for great sums in present,
Or assurances of ample jointures.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: That to me is easy,
For instantly I'll do it, hear me comrades.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What sayst thou Tibalt?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Why, that to woe a wench with empty hands
Is no good heraldy, therefore let's to the gold,
And share it equally: 'twill speak for us
More than a thousand compliments or cringes,
Ditties stolen from Patrick, or discourse from Ovid,
Besides 'twill beget us respect,
And if ever fortune friend us with a bark,
Largely supply us with all provision.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well advised, defer it not.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Are ye all contented.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Let's away then,
Straight we'll return,
And you shall see our riches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Since I know what wonder and amazement was,
I near was so transported.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why weep ye gentle maid?
There is no danger here to such as you;
Banish fear: for with us I dare promise,
You shall meet all courteous entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: We esteem ourselves most happy in you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And bless fortune that brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hark in your ear;
I love you as a friend already,
Ere long you shall call me by a nearer name,
I wish your brother well: I know you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I to my grief I do;
Alas good ladies, there is nothing left me
But thanks to pay ye with. Enter Albert, Tibalt, and the rest with treasure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That's more
Than yet you stand engaged for.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: So soon returned!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hear: see the idol of the lapidary.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: These pearls for which the slavish negro
Dives to the bottom of the sea.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To get which the industrious merchant
Touches at either pole.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The never-failing purchase
Of lordships and of honours.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The world's mistress,
That can give every thing to the possessors.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: For which the sailors scorn tempestuous winds,
And spit defiance in the sea.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Speak lady: look we not lovely now?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes: yes, oh my stars
Be now for ever blessed, that have brought
To my revenge these robbers; take your arrows,
And nail these monsters to the earth.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What mean ye lady?
In what have we offended?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O my daughter!
And you companions with me in all fortunes,
Look on these caskets and these jewels
These were our own, when first we put to sea
With good Sebastian: and these the pirates
That not alone deprived him of this treasure,
But also took his life.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Part of my present
I well remember was mine own.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And these were mine.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Sure, I have worn this jewel.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Wherefore do ye stay then,
And not perform my command?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O heaven!
What cruel fate pursues us.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: I am well enough served,
That must be offering jointures, jewels,
And precious stones more than I brought with me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why, shoot ye not?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hear me dear mother;
And when the greatest cruelty, is justice,
Do not show mercy: death to these starved wretches
Is a reward, not punishment: let 'em live
To undergo the full weight of your displeasure.
And that they may have sense to feel the torments
They have deserved: allow 'em some small pittance,
To linger out their tortures.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: 'Tis well counselled.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: And we'll follow it;
Hear us speak.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Peace dogs.
Bind 'em fast: when fury hath given way to reason,
I will determine of their sufferings,
Which shall be horrid. Vengeance, though slow paced,
At length o'ertakes the guilty; and the wrath
Of the incensed powers will fall most sure
On wicked men, when they are most secure. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: Here's nothing, sir, but poverty and hunger;
No promise of inhabitant; neither tract of beast,
Nor foot of man: we have searched
All this rocky desert, yet cannot discover any assurance
Here is or hath been such men.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: Not a relic of any thing they wore;
Nor mark left by 'em, either to find relief,
Or to warn others from the like misfortune.
Believe it, these fellows are both false,
And to get a little succour in their misery,
Have framed this cunning tale.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The ship, I know, is French, and owned by pirates,
If not by Albert my arch enemy.
You told me too there was a woman with 'em.
A young and handsome woman.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: There was so sir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And such and such young gallants.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: We told ye true sir,
That they had no means to quit this island.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And that amid their mutiny to save your lives
You got their ship.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: All is most certain sir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Where are they then? where are these men
Or woman? we are landed where your faiths
Did assure us we could not miss their sights.
For this news we took ye to our mercy,
Relieved ye, when the furious sea and famine
Strove which should first devour ye;
Clothed, and cherished ye; used ye as those ye say ye are.
Fair gentlemen, now keep your words,
And show us this company, your own free pities spoke of;
These men ye left in misery; the woman.
Men of those noble breedings you pretend to.
Should scorn to lie, or get their food with falsehood;
Come, direct us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Alas sir, they are gone,
But by what means or providence, we know not.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: Was not the captain
A fellow of a fiery, yet brave nature,
A middle stature, and of brown complexion?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: He was sir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: 'Twas Albert,
And my poor wretched sister.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: 'Twas he certain,
I ha' been at sea with him; many times at sea.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Come show us these men;
Show us presently, and do not dally with us.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: We left 'em here; what should we say, sir?
Here in this place.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: The earth cannot swallow 'em;
They have no wings, they cannot fly sure.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: You told us too
Of heaps of treasure, and of sums concealed,
That set their hearts a fire; we see no such thing,
No such sign; what can ye say to purge ye?
What have ye done with these men?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: We, sir?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: You sir;
For certain I believe ye saw such people.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: By all that's good,
By all that's pure and honest,
By all that's holy.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: I dare not credit ye,
Ye have so abused my hope, that now I hate ye.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: Let's put 'em in their ragged clothes again captain,
For certain they are knaves, let's e'en deliver 'em
To their old fruitful farm; here let 'em walk the island.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: If ye do so, we shall curse your mercies.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Rather put us to sea again.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Not so.
Yet this I'll do, because ye say ye are Christians,
Though I hardly credit it: bring in the boat,
And all aboard again, but these two wretches;
Yet leave 'em four days' meat. If in that time,
(For I will search all nooks of this strange island)
I can discover any tract of these men,
Alive or dead, I'll bear ye off, and honour ye;
If not, ye have found your graves; so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: That goodness dwells above, and knows us innocent,
Comfort our lives, and at his pleasure quit us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Come cousin, come; old time will end our story:
But no time (If we end well) ends our glory. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Rossella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, Juletta.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Use 'em with all the austerity that may be,
They are our slaves; turn all those pities,
Those tender reluctations that should become your sex,
To stern anger; and when ye look upon 'em,
Look with those eyes that wept those bitter sorrows,
Those cruelties ye suffered by their rapines.
Some five days hence that blessed hour comes,
Most happy to me, that knit this hand to my dear husbands,
And both our hearts in mutual bands.
That hour ladies.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What of that hour?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why, on that hour daughter,
And in the height of all our celebrations,
Our dear remembrances of that dear man,
And those that suffered with him, our fair kinsmen,
Their lives shall fall a sacrifice to vengeance,
Their lives that ruined his; 'tis a full justice.
I will look glorious in their bloods;
And the most noble spirit of Sebastian,
That perished by the pride of these French pirates,
Shall smile in heaven, and bless the hand that killed 'em.
Look strictly all unto your prisoners;
For he that makes a scape beyond my vengeance,
Or entertains a hope by your fair usage;
Take heed, I say, she that deceives my trust,
Again take heed: her life, and that's but light neither;
Her life in all the tortures my spirit can put on.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We shall be careful.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Do so. Exit Rossella.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are angry mother, and ye are old too,
Forgetting what men are: but we shall temper ye.
How fare your prisoners, ladies? in what forms
Do they appear in their afflictions?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mine fare but poorly;
For so I am commanded: 'tis none of their fault.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Of what sort are they?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They say they are gentlemen.
But they show mongrels.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How do they suffer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Faith like boys;
They are fearful in all fortunes; when I smile
They kneel, and beg to have that face continued;
And like poor slaves, adore the ground I go on.
When I frown, they hang their most dejected heads,
Like fearful sheephounds; show 'em a crust of bread
They'll saint me presently, and skip like apes
For a sup of wine. I'll whip 'em like hackneys,
Saddle 'em, ride 'em, do what I will with 'em.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tush, these are poor things.
Have they names like Christians?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Very fair names: Franvile, Lamure, and Morillat;
And brag of great kindreds too. They offer very handsomely,
But that I am a fool, and dare not venture.
They are sound too i'my conscience,
Or very near upon 't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fie, away fool.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They tell me
If they might be brought before you,
They would reveal things of strange consequence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Their base poor fears.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ay, that makes me hate 'em too;
For if they were but manly to their sufferance,
Sure I should strain a point or two.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: An hour hence I'll take a view of 'em,
And hear their business. Are your men thus too?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Mine? No gentle madam, mine were not cast
In such base moulds; afflictions, tortures,
Are names and natures of delight, to my men;
All sorts of cruelties they meet like pleasures.
I have but two; the one they call Dupont,
Tibalt Dupont; the other the shipmaster.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have they not lives, and fears?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Lives they have madam;
But those lives never linked to such companions
As fears or doubts.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Use 'em nobly;
And where you find fit subjects for your pities
Let it become ye to be courteous;
My mother will not always be thus rigorous.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: Mine are sailors madam,
But they sleep soundly, and seldom trouble me, unless it be when
They dream sometimes of fights and tempests;
Then they roar and whistle for cans of wine,
And down they fling me; and in that rage,
(For they are violent fellows) they play such reaks.
If they have meat, they thank me;
If none, they heartily desire to be hanged quickly.
And this is all they care.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Look to 'em diligently, and where your pities tells ye
They may deserve, give comfort.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come hither, be not frighted;Enter Aminta,
Think not ye steal this liberty, for we give it,
Your tender innocence assures me, virgin,
Ye had no share in those wrongs these men did us;
I find ye are not hardened in such mischiefs.
Your brother was misled sure,
Foully misled.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How much I fear these pities!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Certain he was, so much I pity him;
And for your sake, whose eyes plead for him;
Nay, for his own sake.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: For I see about him
Women have subtle eyes, and look narrowly;
Or I am much abused: many fair promises;
Nay beyond those, too many shadowed virtues.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I think he is good.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I assure myself he will be;
And out of that assurance take this comfort,
For I perceive your fear hath much dejected ye.
I love your brother.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, do not take it for a dreamt of favour,
That comforts in the sleep, and awake vanishes;
Indeed I love him.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do ye indeed?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You doubt still, because ye fear his safety;
Indeed he is the sweetest man I ere saw;
I think the best. Ye may hear without blushes,
And give me thanks, if ye please, for my courtesy.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Madam, I ever must;
Yet witness heaven, they are hard pulled from me.
Believe me, madam, so many imperfections I could find,
(Forgive me grace for lying) and such wants,
('tis to an honest use) such poverties,
Both in his main proportion, and his mind too;
There are a hundred handsomer; (I lie lewdly)
Your noble usage, madam, hath so bound me to ye,
That I must tell ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come tell your worst.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: He is no husband for ye.
I think ye mean in that fair way.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye have hit it.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am sure ye have hit my heart.
You will find him dangerous, madam;
As fickle as the flying air, proud, jealous,
Soon glutted in your sweets, and soon forgetful;
