I could say more, and tell ye I have a brother,
Another brother, that so far excels this,
Both in the ornaments of man, and making.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If you were not his sister, I should doubt ye mainly;
Doubt ye for his love, ye deal so cunningly.
Do not abuse me, I have trusted ye with more than life,
With my first love; be careful of me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: In what use, madam?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: In this lady,
Speak to him for me, you have power upon him;
Tell him I love him, tell him I dote on him.
It will become your tongue.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Become my grave.
O fortune, oh cursed fortune.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tell him his liberty,
And all those with him; all our wealth and jewels.
Good sister, for I'll call ye so.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I shall lady,
Even die, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Here's meat and wine, pray take it,
And there he lies; give him what liberty you please;
But still concealed. What pleasure you shall please, sister.
He shall ne'er want again. Nay, see an you'll take it;
Why do you study thus?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: To avoid mischiefs, if they should happen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Go and be happy for me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O blind fortune;
Yet happy thus far, I shall live to see him,
In what strange desolation lives he here now?
Sure this curtain will reveal. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who's that? ha!
Some gentle hand, I hope, to bring me comfort.
Or if it be my death, 'tis sweetly shadowed.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Have ye forgotten me sir?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My Aminta?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She sir,
That walks here up and down an empty shadow,
One that for some few hours
But wanders here, carrying her own sad coffin,
Seeking some desert place to lodge her griefs in.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet sorrow welcome, welcome noble grief;
How got you this fair liberty to see me?
For sorrows in your shape are strangers to me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to counsel ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are still more welcome;
For good friends in afflictions give good counsels.
Pray then proceed.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Pray eat first, ye show faint;
Here's wine to refresh ye too.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I thank ye dear.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Drink again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Here's to our loves.
How, turn and weep!
Pray pledge it: this happiness we have yet left,
Our hearts are free. Not pledge it? why,
And though beneath the axe this health were holy,
Why do ye weep thus?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to woe ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To woe me sweet? I am wooed and won already,
You know I am yours. This pretty way becomes ye.
But you would deceive my sorrows; that's your intent.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I would I could, I should not weep, but smile.
Do ye like your meat and wine?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Like it?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do you like your liberty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All these I well may like.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Then pray like her that sent 'em.
Do ye like wealth, and most unequalled beauty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Peace, indeed you'll make me angry.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Would I were dead that ask it,
Than ye might freely like, and I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What like, and who? add not more misery
To a man that's fruitful in afflictions.
Who is't you would have me like?
Who sent these comforts?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I must tell.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be bold.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But be you temperate.
If you be bold I die. The young fair virgin;
(Sorrow hath made me old.) O harken,
And wisely hark, the governess daughter:
That star that strikes this island full of wonder,
That blooming sweetness.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She sent it: and with it,
It must be out, she dotes on ye,
And must enjoy ye: else no joy must find ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And have you the patience to deliver this?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A sister may say much, and modestly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A sister?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Yes, that name undid ye;
Undid us both: had ye named wife, she had feared ye;
And feared the sin she followed; she had shunned, yea
Her virgin modesty had not touched at ye.
But thinking you were free, hath kindled a fire,
I fear will hardly be extinguished.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Indeed I played the fool.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my best sir, take heed,
Take heed of lies. Truth though it trouble some minds,
Some wicked minds, that are both dark and dangerous:
Yet it preserves itself, comes off pure, innocent,
And like the sun, though never so eclipsed,
Must break in glory. O sir, lie no more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye have read me a fair lecture,
And put a spell upon my tongue for feigning.
But how will you counsel now?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye must study to forget me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be patient.
Be wise and patient, it concerns ye highly.
Can ye lay by our loves? But why should I doubt it?
Ye are a man, and men may shift affections,
'Tis held no sin. To come to the point,
Ye must lose me; many and mighty reasons.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hear me Aminta,
Have you a man that loves you to, that feeds ye,
That sends ye liberty? has this great governess
A noble son too, young, and apt to catch ye?
Am I because I am in bonds, and miserable,
My health decayed, my youth, and strength half blasted,
My fortune like my wayning self, for this despised?
Am I for this forsaken? A new love chosen,
And my affections, like my fortune's wanderers?
Take heed of lying, you that chid me for it;
And showed how deep a sin it was, and dangerous.
Take heed, yourself, you swore you loved me dear;
No few, nor little oaths you swore Aminta,
Those sealed with no small faith, I then assured myself.
O seek no new ways to cozen truth.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I do not.
By love itself I love thee,
And ever must, nor can all deaths dissolve it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why do you urge me thus then?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: For your safety,
To preserve your life.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My life I do confess is hers,
She gives it,
And let her take it back, I yield it.
My loves entirely thine, none shall touch at it;
None, my Aminta, none.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye have made me happy,
And now I know ye are mine. Fortune, I scorn thee.
Go to your rest, and I'll sit by ye;
Whilst I have time I'll be your mate, and comfort ye,
For only I am trusted: you shall want nothing,
Not a liberty that I can steal ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: May we not celebrate our loves Aminta?
And where our wishes cannot meet

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: You are wanton,
But with cold kisses I'll allay that favour;
Look for no more, and that in private too.
Believe me I shall blush else.
But let's consider, we are both lost else.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let's in, and prevent fate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You do well to air us ladies, we shall be musty else.
What are your wise wills now?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are very crank still.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: As crank as a holy friar, fed with hailstones.
But do ye bring us out to bait, like bulls?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Or are you weary of the charge ye are at?
Turn us abroad again, let's jog ladies;
We are gross, and course, unfit for your sweet pleasures.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Knock off our shoes, and turns to grass.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are determined
Still to be stubborn then: it well becomes ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: An humour lady that contents a prisoner.
A sullen fit sometimes serves for a second course.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye may as well be kind,
And gain our favours; gain meat, and drink,
And lodging to rest your bones.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: My bones have bore me thus long,
And had their share of pains, and recreations;
If they fail now, they are no fair companions.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Are ye thus harsh to all our sex?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We cannot be merry without a fiddler.
Pray strike up your tabors, ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: The fools despise us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We know ye are very hungry now.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis very wholesome ladies;
For we that have gross bodies, must be careful.
Have ye no piercing air to stir our stomachs?
We are beholding to ye for our ordinary.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why slaves, 'tis in our power to hang ye.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Very likely.
'Tis in our powers then to be hanged, and scorn ye.
Hanging's as sweet to us, as dreaming to you.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come, be more courteous.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do, and than ye shall be pleased, and have all necessaries.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Give me some ratsbane then.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: And why ratsbane, monsieur?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: We live like vermin here, and eat up your cheese,
Your mouldy cheese, that none but rats would bite at;
Therefore 'tis just that ratsbane should reward us.
We are unprofitable, and our ploughs are broken;
There is no hope of harvest this year, ladies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye shall have all content.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ay, and we'll serve your uses.
I had rather serve hogs, there's more delight in't;
Your greedy appetites are never satisfied;
Just like hungry camels, sleeping or waking
You chew the cud still.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: By this hand we'll starve ye.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble courtesy.
I had as lief ye should famish me, as founder me,
To be jaded to death is only fit for a hackney.
Here be certain tarts of tar about me,
And parcels of potargo in my jerkin,
As long as these last.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Which will not last ever.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then we'll eat one another like good fellows,
A shoulder of his for a haunch of mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: 'Twill be, as we'll dress it ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Why sure ye are not men.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ye had best come search us,
A seaman is seldom without a salt eel.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am bad enough,
And in my nature a notorious wencher;
And yet ye make me blush at your immodesty.
Tell me good master, didst ever see such things?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I could like 'em though they were lewdly given,
If they could say no; but fie on 'em,
They gape like oysters.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Well, ye may hang, or starve us;
But your commanding impudence shall never fear us.
Had ye by blushing signs, soft cunnings, crept into us,
And showed us your necessities: we had met your purposes,
Supplied your wants. We are no saints ladies;
I love a good wench, as I love my life,
And with my life I will maintain my love:
But such a sordid impudence I'll spit at.
Let's to our dens again. Come noble master.
You know our minds ladies:
This is the faith in which we'll die. Exit Tib. and mast.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I do admire 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are noble fellows,
And they shall not want, for this.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: But see, Clarinda comes. Enter Clarinda.
Farewell, I'll to my charge.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Bring out those prisoners now,
And let me see 'em, and hear their business.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will, madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I hope she hath prevailed upon her brother.
She has a sweet tongue, and can describe the happiness
My love is ready to fling on him.
And sure he must be glad, and certain wonder
And bless the hour that brought him to this island.
I long to hear the full joy that he labours with.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Bless thy divine beauty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mirror of sweetness.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ever springing brightness.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, stand up gentlemen, and leave your flatteries.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: She calls us gentlemen, sure we shall have some meat now.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am a mortal creature,
Worship heaven, and give these attributes
To their divinities. Methinks ye look but thin.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O we are starved, immortal beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We are all poor starved knaves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Neither liberty nor meat lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We were handsome men, and gentlemen, and sweet men,
And were once gracious in the eyes of beauties,
But now we look like rogues;
Like poor starved rogues.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would ye do if ye were to die now?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas we were prepared. If you will hang us,
Let's have a good meal or two to die with,
To put's in heart.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or if you'll drown us,
Let's be drunk first, that we may die merrily,
And bless the founders.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye shall not die so hastily.
What dare ye do to deserve my favour?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Put us to any service.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Any bondage,
Let's but live.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We'll get a world of children,
For we know, ye are heinously provided that way;
And ye shall beat us when we offend ye;
Beat us abundantly, and take our meat from us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: These are weak abject things, that show ye poor ones.
What's the great service ye so oft have threatened,
If ye might see me, and win my favour?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That business of discovery.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O, I'll tell ye lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I,
Pray let me speak first.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good, no confusion.
We are before a lady that knows manners;
And by the next, meat I shall eat, 'tis certain.
This little gentlewoman that was taken with us

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your captain's sister, she you mean.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ay, ay, she's the business that we would open to ye.
You are cozened in her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, what is't you would open?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is no sister.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good sirs, how quick you are.
She is no sister, madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is his.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Peace I say.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Faith, sweet lady,
She is, as a man would say, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His mistress.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or, as some new translators read, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And why he should delude you thus,
Unless he meant some villainy? these ten weeks
He has had her at sea for his own proper appetite.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His cabin-mate, I'll assure ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No sister, say ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No more than I am brother to your beauty.
I know not why he should juggle thus.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do not lie to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: If ye find me lie, lady, hang me empty.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How am I fooled!
Away with 'em, Juletta, and feed 'em
But hark ye, with such food as they have given me.
New misery!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nor meat, nor thanks for all this. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Make 'em more wretched.
O I could burst! curse and kill now,
Kill any thing I meet. Juletta, follow me,
And call the rest along.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We follow madam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I must be gone now, else she may suspect me;
How shall I answer her?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Tell her directly.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: That were too sudden, too improvident;
Fires of this nature must be put out cunningly,
They'll waste all come near 'em else.
Farewell once more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Farewell.
And keep my love entire.
Nay kiss me once again, methinks we should not part.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O be wise, sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, one kiss more.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Indeed you're wanton;Enter Clarinda, Juletta, crolale, Hippolita.
We may be taken too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Out thou base woman.
By heaven I'll shoot 'em both.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Nay stay, brave lady, hold;
A sudden death cuts of a nobler vengeance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I made bawd to your lascivious meetings?
Are ye grown so wise in sin?
Shut up that villain: and sirrah,
Now expect my utmost anger.
Let him there starve.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ay, mock at your mischiefs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tie that false witch unto that tree,
There let the savage beasts
Gnaw of her sweetness, and snakes
Embrace her beauties; tie her, and watch
That none relieve her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We could wish ye better fortune lady,
But dare not help ye.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be your own friends, I thank ye.
Now only my last audit, and my greatest,Enter Raymond.
O heaven, be kind unto me,
And if it be thy will, preserve.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Who is this?
Sure 'tis a woman; I have trod this place,
And found much footing: now I know 'tis peopled.
Ha, let me see! 'tis her face.
O heaven! turn this way maid.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O Raymond, oh brother.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Her tongue to: 'tis my sister; what rude hand!
Nay kiss me first, oh joy!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Fly, fly dear brother,
You are lost else.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A man, a man, a new man.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: What are these? Enter Juletta, Crocale, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: An enemy, an enemy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dispatch him,
Take him off, shoot him straight.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: I dare not use my sword, ladies,
Against such comely foes.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O brother brother!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Away with 'em, and in dark prisons bind 'em.
One word replied, ye die both.
Now brave mother follow thy noble anger,
And I'll help thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Rossella, Clarinda, Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am deaf to all your entreaties: she that moves me
For pity or compassion to these pirates,
Digs up her fathers, or her brother's tomb,
And spurns about their ashes.
Couldst thou remember what a father thou hast once,
'Twould steel thy heart against foolish pity.
By his memory, and the remembrance of his dear embraces,
I am taught, that in a noble cause revenge is noble;
And they shall fall the sacrifices to appease
His wandering ghost, and my incensed fury.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The new come prisoner to?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Him to. Yet that we may learn
Whether they are the same, or near allied
To those that forced me to this cruel course,
Better their poor allowance, and permit 'em
To meet together and confer,
Within the distance of your ear; perhaps
They may discover something that may kill
Despair in me, and be a means to save 'em
From certain ruin.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: That shall be my charge.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yet to prevent
All hope of rescue: for this new come captain
Hath both a ship and men not far off from us,
Though ignorant to find the only port,
That can yield entrance to our happy island,
Guard the place strongly, and ere the next sun
Ends his diurnal progress, I will be
Happy in my revenge, or set 'em free. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita. A table furnished.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: So serve it plentifully,
And lose not time to inquire the cause;
There is a main design that hangs upon this bounty.
See the table furnished with wine too,
That discovers secrets which tortures cannot open:
Open the doors too of the several prisons,
And give all free entrance into this room.
Undiscovered I can here mark all. Enter Tib. mast.
Here's captain careless, and the tough shipmaster,
The slaves are nosed like vultures
How wild they look.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ha, the mystery of this,
Some good hobgoblin rise and reveal.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I am amazed at it: nor can I sound the intent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Is not this bread,
Substantial bread, not painted?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: But take heed,
You may be poisoned.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am sure I am famished;
And as the wise man says,
Gripes the guts as much as any mineral.
This may be treacle sent to preserve me
After a long fast: or be it viper's spittle,
I'll run the hazard.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We are passed all fear, I'll take part with ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Do: and now i'faith, how d'ye feel yourself?
I find great ease in't. What's here?
Wine, and it be thy will;
Strong lusty wine. Well, fools may talk
Of mitridiate, cordials, and elixars.
But from my youth this was my only physic.
Here's a colour, what lady's cheek,
Though cerused over, comes near it?
It sparkles too: hangs out diamonds.
O my sweet heart, how I will hug thee,
Again, and again! They are poor drunkards,
And not worth thy favours,
That number thy moist kisses in these crystals.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: But mounsiver,
Here are suckets, and sweet dishes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Tush, boys meat,
I am past it; here's strong food fit for men:
Nectar, old lad. Mistress of merry hearts,
Once more I am bold with you.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Take heed (Man)
Too much will breed distemper.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hast thou lived at sea
The most part of thy life, where to be sober
While we have wine aboard, is capital treason;
And dost thou preach sobriety?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Prithee forbear,
We may offend in it; we know not for whom
It was provided.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am sure for me: therefore foutra,
When I am full, let 'em hang me, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This has been his temper ever. Enter Albert, Aminta, Raymond, Lamure, Morrillat, Franvile, severally.
See, provoking dishes, candid eringoes,
And potatoes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I'll not touch 'em, I will drink;
But not a bit on a march, I'll be an eunuch rather.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Who are these?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Marry, who you will;
I keep my text here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Raymond!

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Albert!

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Away, I'll be drunk alone;
Keep off rogues, or I'll belch ye into air;
Not a drop here.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Dear brother, put not in your eyes such anger;
Those looks poisoned with fury shot at him,
Reflect on me. O brother look milder, or
The crystal of his temperance
Will turn 'em on yourself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir have sought ye long
To find your pardon: you have ploughed the ocean
To wreak your vengeance on me, for the rape
Of this fair virgin. Now our fortune guides us
To meet on such hard terms, that we need rather
A mutual pity of our present state,
Then to expostulate of breaches past,
Which cannot be made up. And though it be
Far from your power to force me to confess,
That I have done ye wrong, or such submission
Failing to make my peace, to vent your anger;
You being yourself slaved, as I to others:
Yet for your sister's sake, her blessed sake,
In part of recompense of what she has suffered
For my rash folly; the contagion
Of my black actions catching hold upon
Her purer innocence: I crave your mercy,
And wish however several motives kept us
From being friends while we had hope to live,
Let death which we expect, and cannot fly from,
End all contention.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Drink upon't, 'tis a good motion;
Ratify it in wine, and 'tis authentical.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: When I consider
The ground of our long difference, and look on
Our not to be avoided miseries,
It doth beget in me I know not how
A soft religious tenderness; which tells me,
Though we have many faults to answer for
Upon our own account, our father's crimes
Are in us punished. O Albert, the course
They took to leave us rich was not honest,
Nor can that friendship last, which virtue joins not.
When first they forced the industrious Portugals,
From their plantations in the happy islands.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: This is that I watch for.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And did omit no tyranny, which men
Enured to spoil and mischief could inflict,
On the grieved sufferers; when by lawless rapine
They reaped the harvest, which their labours sowed;
And not content to force 'em from their dwelling,
But laid for 'em at sea, to ravish from 'em
The last remainder of their wealth; then, then,
After a long pursuit, each doubting other,
As guilty of the Portugals escape,
They did begin to quarrel, like ill men;
(Forgive me piety, that I call 'em so)
No longer love, or correspondence holds,
Than it is cemented with prey or profit:
Then did they turn those swords they oft had bloodied
With innocent gore, upon their wretched selves,
And paid the forfeit of their cruelty
Shown to Sebastian, and his colony,
By being fatal enemies to each other.
Thence grew Amyntas rape, and my desire
To be revenged. And now observe the issue:
As they for spoil ever forgotten compassion
To women, (Who should be exempted
From the extremities of a lawful war)
We now, young able men, are fallen into
The hands of women; that, against the soft
Tenderness familiar to their sex,Enter Crocale.
Will show no mercy.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: None, unless you show us
Our long lost husbands.
We are those Potugals you talked of.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Stay,
I met upon the sea in a tall ship
Two Portugals, famished almost to death.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Our ship by this wine.
And those the rogues that stole her,
Left us to famish in the barren islands.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Some such tale they told me,
And something of a woman, which I find,
To be my sister.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Where are these men?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I left 'em,
Supposing they had deluded me with forged tales,
In the island where they said
They had lived many years the wretched owners
Of a huge mass of treasure.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The same men: and that the fatal muck
We quarreled for.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They were Portugal's you say.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: So they professed.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They may prove such men as may save your lives,
And so much I am taken with fair hope,
That I will hazard life to be resolved on't:
How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: My ship lies by the river's mouth,
That can convey ye to these wretched men,
Which you desire to see.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Back to your prisons,
And pray for the success: if they be those
Which I desire to find, you are safe;
If not, prepare to die tomorrow:
For the world cannot redeem ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: However , we are armed
For either fortune,Exit.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: What must become of me now
That I am not dismissed?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: O sir, I purpose
To have your company.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Take heed wicked woman,
I am apt to mischief now.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You cannot be so unkind,
To her that gives you liberty.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: No, I shall be too kind, that's the devil on't;
I have had store of good wine: and when I am drunk,
Joan is a lady to me, and I shall
Lay about me like a lord: I feel strange motions:
Avoid me temptation.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come sir, I'll help ye in. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: What may that be
That moves upon the lake?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still it draws nearer,
And now I plainly can discern it.
'Tis the French ship.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: In it a woman,
Who seems to invite us to her,

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still she calls with signs of love to hasten to her;
So lovely hope doth still appear:
I feel nor age nor weakness.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Though it bring death,
To us 'tis comfort: and deserves a meeting.
Or else fortune tired with what we have suffered,
And in it overcome, as it may be,
Now sets a period to our misery. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What dreadful sounds are these?

sp.speaker: Amin
sp.l: Infernal music,
Fit for a bloody feast.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It seems prepared
To kill our courages, ere they divorce
Our souls and bodies.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: But they that fearless fall,
Deprive them of their triumph.

div.stage: Enter Rossillia, Clarinda, Julletta, Hippollitta, etc.

sp.speaker: Aminta
sp.l: See the furies,
In their full trim of cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: 'Tis the last
Duty that I can pay to my dead lord,
Set out the altar, I myself will be
The priest, and boldly do those horrid rites
You shake to think on: lead these captains nearer,
For they shall have the honour to fall first
To my Sebastian's ashes: and now wretches,
As I am taught already that you are,
And lately by your free confession,
French pirates, and the sons of those I hate,
Even equal with the devil; here with horror,
What 'tis invites me to this cruel course,
And what you are to suffer; no Amazons we,
But women of Portugal, that must have from you
Sebastian and Nicusa; we are they
That groaned beneath your father's wrongs:
We are those wretched women,
Their injuries pursued, and overtook;
And from the sad remembrance of our losses
We are taught to be cruel; when we were forced
From that sweet air we breathed in, by their rapine,
And sought a place of being; as the seas
And winds conspired with their ill purposes,
To load us with afflictions, in a storm
That fell upon us; the two ships that brought us,
To seek new fortunes in an unknown world
Were severed: the one bore all the able men,
Our treasure and our jewels: in the other,
We women were embarked: and fell upon,
After long tossing in the troubled main,
This pleasant island: but in few months,
The men that did conduct us hither died,
We long before had given our husbands lost:
Remembering what we had suffered by the French,
We took a solemn oath never to admit
The cursed society of men: necessity
Taught us those arts not usual to our sex:
And the fertile earth yielding abundance to us,
We did resolve thus shaped like Amazons
To end our lives; but when you arrived here,
And brought as presents to us our own jewels;
Those which were borne in the other ship,
How can ye hope to scape our vengeance?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: It boots not then to swear our innocence?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Or that we never forced it from the owners?

sp.speaker: Ray
sp.l: Or that there are a remnant of that wrack,
And not far off?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: All you affirm, I know,
Is but to win time; therefore prepare your throats,
The world shall not redeem ye: and that your cries
May find no entrance to our ears,
To move pity in any: bid loud music sound
Their fatal kneels; if ye have prayers use 'em quickly,
To any power will own yea; but ha! Enter Crocale, Sebastian, Nicusa, Tibalt.
Who are these? what spectacles of misfortune?
Why are their looks
So full of joy and wonder?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Oh! lay by
These instruments of death, and welcome
To your arms what you durst never hope to embrace:
This is Sebastian, this Nicusa madam:
Preserved by miracle: look up dear sir,
And know your own Rossellia: be not lost
In wonder and amazement; or if nature
Can by instinct instruct you what it is,
To be blessed with the name of father,
Freely enjoy it in this fair virgin.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Though my miseries,
And many years of wants, I have endured,
May well deprave me of the memory
Of all joys past; yet looking on this building,
This ruind building of a heavenly form
In my Rossella; I must remember, I am Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O my joys!

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: And here,
I see a perfect model of thyself,
As thou wert when thy choice first made thee mine:
These cheeks and fronts though wrinkled now with time
Which art cannot restore: had equal pureness,
Of natural white and red, and as much ravishing:
Which by fair order and succession,
I see descend on her: and may thy virtue's
Wind into her form, and make her a perfect dower:
No part of thy sweet goodness wanting to her.
I will not now Rossellia ask thy fortunes,
Nor trouble thee with hearing mine;
Those shall hereafter serve to make glad hours
In their relation: all past wrongs forgotten;
I am glad to see you gentlemen; but most,
That it is in my power to save your lives;
You saved ours when we were near starved at sea,
And I despair not, for if she be mine?
Rossellia can deny Sebastian nothing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She does give up herself,
Her power and joys, and all, to you,
To be discharged of 'em as too burdensome;
Wellcome in any shape.

sp.speaker: Sabast.
sp.l: Sir in your looks,
I read your suit of my Clarinda: she is yours:
And lady if it be in me to confirm
Your hopes in this brave gentleman,
Presume I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O happy hour!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O my dear Aminta;
Now all our fears are ended.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here I fix: she's mettle,
Steel to the back: and will cut my leaden dagger,
If not used with discretion.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are still no changeling.

sp.speaker: Sabast.
sp.l: Nay,
All look cheerfully, for none shall be
Denied their lawful wishes; when a while
We have here refreshed ourselves; we'll return
To our several homes; and well that voyage ends,
That makes of deady enemies' faithful friends.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
